http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: A reference to a document.

group.title: A reference to a document
group.text: Usually, this is used for documents other than those defined by FHIR.

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: The logical id of the resource, as used in the url for the resoure. Once assigned, this value never changes. The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation. Bundles always have an id, though it is usually a generated UUID.
The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.
unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

The version specific identifier, as it appears in the version portion of the url. This values changes when the resource is created, updated, or deleted. The server assigns this value, and ignores what the client specifies, except in the case that the server is imposing version integrity on updates/deletes.

When the resource last changed - e.g. when the version changed. This value is always populated except when the resource is first being created. The server / resource manager sets this value; what a client provides is irrelevant.

question.text: When the resource version last changed

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: A list of profiles that this resource claims to conform to. The URL is a reference to Profile.url. It is up to the server and/or other infrastruture of policy to determine whether/how these claims are verified and/or updated over tiem.

question.text: Profiles this resource claims to conform to

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: Security labels applied to this resource. These tags connect specific resources to the overall security policy and infrastructure. The security labels can be updated without changing the stated version of the resource.

question.text: Security Labels applied to this resource

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: Tags applied to this resource. Tags are intended to to be used to identify and relate resources to process and workflow, and applications are not required to consider the tags when interpreting the meaning of a resource. The tags can be updated without changing the stated version of the resource.

A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element as much as possible.

question.text: A set of rules under which this content was created

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString:
The base language in which the resource is written. Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource

Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety. Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative.

group.text: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope. This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.

group.text: Contained, inline Resources

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: Document identifier as assigned by the source of the document. This identifier is specific to this version of the document. This unique identifier may be used elsewhere to identify this version of the document.

group.text: Master Version Specific Identifier

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString:
Other identifiers associated with the document, including version independent, source record and workflow related identifiers. Other identifiers can also include Identifiers may be Accession Numbers, Order Numbers, Referral Request 
Identifiers, XDS Workflow Instance Identifiers.

group.text: Other identifiers for the document

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: Who or what the document is about. The document can be about a person, (patient or healthcare practitioner), a device (I.e. machine) or even a group of subjects (such as a document about a herd of farm animals, or a set of patients that share a common exposure).

group.text: Who|what is the subject of the document

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: Specifies the particular kind of document (e.g. Patient Summary, Discharge Summary, Prescription, etc.). Key metadata element describing the document, used in searching/filtering.

group.text: What kind of document this is (LOINC if possible)

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: A categorization for the type of the document. This may be implied by or derived from the code specified in the Document Type. Helps humans to assess whether the document is of interest when viewing an index of documents.

group.text: Categorization of Document

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: Identifies who is responsible for adding the information to the document. Not necessarily who did the actual data entry (i.e. typist) it in or who was the source (informant).

group.text: Who and/or what authored the document

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: Identifies the organization or group who is responsible for ongoing maintenance of and access to the document. Identifies the logical organization to go to find the current version, where to report issues, etc. This is different from the physical location of the document, which is the technical location of the document, which host may be delegated to the management of some other organization.
A reference to a domain or server that manages policies under which the document is accessed and/or made available.

question.text: Manages access policies for the document

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: Which person or organization authenticates that this document is valid.

group.text: Who/What authenticated the document

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: When the document was created. Creation time is used for tracking, organizing versions and searching. This is the creation time of the document, not the source material on which it is based.
When the document reference was created. Referencing/indexing time is used for tracking, organizing versions and searching.
The status of this document reference.
The status of the underlying document.

group.text: preliminary | final | appended | amended | entered in error

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: Relationships that this document has with other document references that already exist.
unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

The type of relationship that this document has with anther document. If this document appends another document, then the document cannot be fully understood without also accessing the referenced document.
The target document of this relationship.

Human-readable description of the source document. This is sometimes known as the "title". What the document is about, rather than a terse summary of the document. It is commonly the case that records do not have a title and are collectively referred to by the display name of Record code (e.g. a "consultation" or "progress note").

A code specifying the level of confidentiality of the XDS Document. The interpretation of this field, and more generally enforcement and issues related to highly sensitive documents are beyond the scope of this resource. confidentialityCode can only be understood in the context of the policies, procedures, and value set specified by the context in which the document reference is being used.

group.text: Sensitivity of source document

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: The primary language in which the source document is written.
The mime type of the source document. Note: application/hl7-v3+xml for CDA. application/binary for proprietary record formats.

An identifier that identifies that the format and content of the document conforms to additional rules beyond the base format indicated in the mimeType. Most often used when the mime-type is text/xml.
The size of the source document this reference refers to in bytes.

question.text: Size of the document in bytes

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: A hash of the source document to ensure that changes have not occurred. Whether the hash must be present and/or correct depends on the document handling rules defined in the context of use.

group.text: Base64 representation of SHA1

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: A url at which the document can be accessed.
A description of a service call that can be used to retrieve the document.

group.title: If access is not fully described by location
group.text: If a document can be accessed by either a service or directly by a URL (i.e. an XDS repository with an MHD access point, or a DICOM network with a WADO portal) just provide the URL.

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).
The type of the service that can be used to access the documents. The meaning and interpretation of the parameters depends on the service type.

group.text: Type of service (i.e. XDS.b)

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: Where the service end-point is located. Usually this is a URL, but for some services, the end-point is a simple network name or address that is not a valid URL.

question.text: Where service is located (usually a URL)

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: A list of named parameters that is used in the service call.

group.title: Service call parameters
group.text: The interpretation of the parameters, and how to convert them into a proper service call, is dependent on the type of the service, and needs to be specified in an implementation guide somewhere.

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).
The name of a parameter.
The value of the named parameter.
The clinical context in which the document was prepared.

group.title: Clinical context of document
group.text: These values are primarily added to help with searching for interesting/relevant documents.

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

This list of codes represents the main clinical acts, such as a colonoscopy or an appendectomy, being documented. In some cases, the event is inherent in the typeCode, such as a "History and Physical Report" in which the procedure being documented is necessarily a "History and Physical" act. An event can further specialize the act inherent in the type, such as 
where it is simply "Procedure Report" and the procedure was a "colonoscopy". If one or more event codes are included, they shall not conflict with the values inherent in the class or type elements as such a conflict would create an ambiguous situation.

group.text: Main Clinical Acts Documented

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: The time period over which the service that is described by the document was provided.

group.text: Time of service that is being documented

http://hl7.org/fhir/Profile/questionnair.valueString: The kind of facility where the patient was seen.

group.text: Kind of facility where patient was seen
